newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korea's president faces new calls for apology.
newsitem.headline: S.Korea's president faces new calls for apology.

text.p: Angered by President Kim Young-sam's response to demands that he reveal details of his election campaign financing, South Korean opposition parties on Monday demanded an independent probe and an apology.
But the National Congress for New Politics and the smaller United Liberal Democrats stopped short of calling on Kim to step down.
Instead, they warned that unless the president came clean on his 1992 campaign funding, there could be public calls for his resignation.
The two parties allege that Kim's 1992 election was bankrolled in part by the scandal-hit Hanbo Group, and far exceeded legal spending limits.

The accusations strike at the heart of Kim's presidency since he was swept to power on a promise to clean up corrupt politics and his two predecessors were jailed for taking massive kickbacks from businesses.
Last week, Kim was quoted as saying no records of his campaign spending existed, and digging up the issue would only throw the country into further turmoil.
The president called on all parties to show "apologetic feelings" and reform the system of election campaign funding.
His comments did not go nearly far enough for the opposition, which has seized on the issue ahead of presidential elections in December.

"President Kim Young-sam must reveal his presidential election funds and apologise before the National Assembly," the two parties said in separate statements. If Kim refused, it "could lead to the people asking for a resignation".
Political analysts said opposition leaders faced a quandry over how far to press the issue since questions had also been raised about their own campaign money.

"This is a catch 22," said Yonsei University political science professor Moon Chung-in. "If they push too hard and Kim resigns, opposition leaders will face questions on the legality of their own election funding."
President Kim had been widely expected to issue a public apology and comment on campaign financing after his son, Kim Hyun-chul, was arrested this month on bribery charges.
The opposition alleges that the younger Kim, a key member of Kim's election team, managed millions of dollars of unused campaign funds through business cronies.
Opposition parties also claim that Kim's administration arranged massive loans to Hanbo to repay a political favour.

The collapse of Hanbo's steelmaking flagship in January under five trillion won ($5.6 billion) of debts uncovered a web of corruption linking the group to top presidential aides, politicians and bankers.
Later on Monday, National Congress leader Kim Dae-jung emphasised that opposition groups were not demanding that Kim quit before his single term expires in February next year.
"As long as Kim Young-sam follows our requests, we will help him. We don't want him to face resignation either," he told a televised news conference.
Meanwhile, state prosecutors on Monday extended for a further 10 days the arrest of Kim Hyun-chul, who has not yet been formally indicted on the bribery and tax evasion charges.
The arrest of Kim's son was the biggest blow yet to his presidency, already in deep crisis since the collapse of Hanbo Steel Co in a sleaze scandal.
(Conversion: $1 = 891 won)
